did.unittitle: Rittenhouse family papers and William Rittenhouse indenture

bioghist.p: The Rittenhouse family were paper-makers in Germany and Holland. In 1687 or 1688, William Rittenhouse (1644-1708) (originally called Wilhelm Rittinghausen), his sons Claus (1666-1734) and Garret (1674-1742), and his daughter Elizabeth (b. ca. 1670) emigrated to the United States. By 1689 they were established in the Philadelphia area. In 1690, William Rittenhouse, together with William Bradford, the printer, and two other investors, Robert Turner and Thomas Treese, opened the first American paper mill, on Wissahickon Creek in Roxborough, Pennsylvania. The descendants of William Rittenhouse, including his son Claus, his grandson William 2nd, his great grandson Jacob and another relative, possibly also a great-grandson, Nicholas Rittenhouse, continued to operate the mill until the mid 19th century. William's great-grandson, David Rittenhouse (1732-1796), was a mathematician and astronomer and, during the Revolution, he was in charge of the Safety Committee in Philadelphia, which was responsible for recruitment.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of papers of the Rittenhouse family. Documents related to William Rittenhouse and his sons Claus and Jacob include indentures, receipts, and correspondence. Of note is the 1706 indenture for the property on which the Rittenhouse paper mill was built, a plan for the new mill (undated), and the last will and testament of Claus Rittenhouse. The collection also includes correspondence between Nicholas Rittenhouse and his son Josiah, and invitations and certificates related to various Civil War memorials belonging to Nicholas Martin Rittenhouse.
